content: The "Protect and Preserve International Cultural Property Act" defines cultural property as outlined in the Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict. The appropriate congressional committees are specified as the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate. SEC. 3. FINDINGS AND STATEMENT OF POLICY. Congress finds that protecting international cultural property is crucial for US cultural diplomacy, as it demonstrates respect for other cultures and the shared heritage of humanity. This protection is necessary due to the loss, damage, and destruction of cultural property caused by various threats such as political instability, armed conflict, and natural disasters. Recent political unrest in Egypt has resulted in the looting of museums and the irreversible destruction of ancient artifacts, creating gaps in the historical record of the Egyptian civilization. In Iraq, looting of the Iraq Museum in Baghdad led to the loss of 15,000 ancient items, including amulets, sculptures, and cylinder seals. In Syria, the civil war has caused damage to UNESCO World Heritage Sites, medieval cities, and looting of museums and archaeological sites dating back over six millennia. In Iraq and Syria, ISIS/ISIL has destroyed cultural sites and artifacts, while in Mali, Ansar Dine destroyed tombs and shrines in Timbuktu. In Timbuktu, a major center for trade, scholarship, and Islam in the 15th and 16th centuries, collections of ancient manuscripts were threatened. In Afghanistan, the Taliban destroyed the Bamiyan Buddhas, ancient statues carved into a cliff side, leading to worldwide condemnation. In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge systematically destroyed many Buddhist temples and desecrated statues after seizing power in 1975. In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge destroyed Buddhist temples, desecrated statues, and literature. In China, the Cultural Revolution led to the destruction of antiques and parts of old Beijing. In Haiti, the 2010 earthquake destroyed art, artifacts, and archives, as well as partially damaging the 17th century city of Jacmel. The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami also caused significant destruction. The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami caused massive loss of life and damage to cultural heritage sites in eleven countries, including Mahabalipuram in India, Sun Temple of Koranak, and Old Town of Galle in Sri Lanka. This destruction represents a loss of humanity's cultural heritage and the United States Armed Forces have played a role in preserving such properties. President Franklin D. Roosevelt established the American Commission for the Protection and Salvage of Artistic and Historic Monuments in War Areas in 1943 to provide expert advice to the military on protecting cultural property. The Commission formed Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives (MFAA) teams, known as the "Monuments Men," who secured and catalogued cultural treasures during wartime. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was founded in 2006 to support the implementation of the 1954 Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict. It works with the U.S. military and other organizations to preserve international cultural property threatened by various disasters. The United States policy is to protect international cultural property at risk of destruction due to political instability, armed conflict, or natural disasters. This includes fulfilling obligations under the 1954 Hague Convention and preventing the importation of cultural property in accordance with existing laws. The United States aims to prevent the importation of cultural property pillaged, looted, or stolen during political instability, armed conflict, or disasters. This includes enforcing existing laws and regulations to stop the trafficking of stolen or looted cultural property. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection is established under Section 4. The President appoints a White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection to coordinate and promote efforts involving multiple Federal agencies in protecting international cultural property. The Coordinator submits an annual report to congressional committees on interagency protection efforts. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection submits an annual report to congressional committees on interagency efforts to protect international cultural property. The report includes policy recommendations, resolves interagency differences, and collaborates with various domestic and international actors to promote and protect cultural property. SEC. 5. INFORMATION ON ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY. The Secretary of State must provide information to the White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection on efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities related to the Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict. This includes procedures implemented to safeguard cultural property at risk due to political instability or armed conflict. The Department of State must report on efforts to protect international cultural property in conflicts, including actions taken to safeguard cultural property at risk due to political instability, armed conflict, or disasters. Additionally, USAID must provide information on its activities to protect international cultural property to the White House. International Development (USAID) must report to the White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection on efforts to protect international cultural property, including coordination with other agencies and organizations. The Department of Defense also needs to provide information on its activities to protect international cultural property to the White House Coordinator. The Department of Defense must report to the White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection on efforts to protect international cultural property, including directives, policies, regulations, and actions taken to safeguard cultural property at risk of destruction. The Department of Justice, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, must provide information on efforts to protect international cultural property, including property abroad and in the United States. The Department of Justice must provide information on efforts to protect international cultural property, including statutes, regulations, and actions taken to prevent trafficking in stolen and smuggled cultural property. The Department of Justice must protect international cultural property, including items located in or imported into the United States. Authorization for federal agencies to engage in international cultural property protection activities with the Smithsonian Institution is granted under Section 6 of the Act. The Department of State, Defense, USAID, Homeland Security, Justice, Interior, National Archives, National Science Foundation, and other agencies can partner with the Smithsonian Institution to temporarily use their personnel for international cultural property protection activities. Federal agencies can use personnel from the Smithsonian Institution to assist in international cultural property protection activities, including support for military, diplomatic, and law enforcement efforts. The Secretary of State is authorized to provide grants for international cultural property protection activities in areas at risk of destruction. Additionally, emergency protection for Syrian cultural property is emphasized. The President will apply import restrictions on archaeological and ethnological material of Syria as if Syria were a State Party to the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act, with the restrictions taking effect within 60 days of the enactment of the Act. The Act mandates import restrictions on archaeological and ethnological material of Syria within 60 days of enactment. Definitions include cultural property unlawfully removed from Syria since August 18, 2011, and the term "State Party" refers to countries under the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act.
